title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #81: Clique Partitions of Chordal Graphs**

**Question:** For a chordal graph G on n vertices, can its edges be partitioned into n²/6 + O(n) cliques?

**Status:** OPEN

**Gap:** Current bounds are (1/4 - ε)n² (upper) vs n²/6 (lower).
mathContext: Chordal graphs have no induced cycles > 3. The clique partition number measures how efficiently edges can be grouped into complete subgraphs.

title: Chordal Graph
content:
**IsChordal G:**

A graph is chordal if it has no induced cycles of length > 3.

**Equivalently:** Every cycle of length ≥ 4 has a chord (an edge between non-adjacent cycle vertices).

**Examples:**
- Trees: chordal (no cycles at all)
- Complete graphs: chordal
- Cycles C_k for k ≥ 4: NOT chordal

title: Clique Partition
content:
**CliquePartition G:**

A partition of all edges into disjoint cliques.

**Requirements:**
1. Each set is a clique (complete subgraph)
2. Every edge is in exactly one clique

The clique partition number is the minimum number of cliques needed.

title: Split Graph
content:
**IsSplitGraph G:**

A graph where vertices partition into:
- K: a clique (all pairwise adjacent)
- I: an independent set (no edges within)

Split graphs are chordal - they have no induced cycles ≥ 4.

The extremal construction for Problem #81 is a split graph.

title: Extremal Construction
content:
**extremal_construction_exists:**

For any n, there exists a chordal graph needing ≥ n²/6 cliques.

**Construction:**
- Take K_{n/3} (complete graph on n/3 vertices)
- Add 2n/3 isolated vertices
- Connect every K_{n/3} vertex to every isolated vertex

This split graph requires ~n²/6 cliques.

title: Erdős-Ordman-Zalcstein Upper Bound
content:
**erdos_ordman_zalcstein (1993):**

Every chordal graph on n vertices has a clique partition with ≤ (1/4 - ε)n² cliques.

**Note:** The ε is very small but positive.

**Gap:** 1/4 ≈ 0.25 vs 1/6 ≈ 0.167 (factor ~1.5)

title: Chen-Erdős-Ordman Split Graph Bound
content:
**chen_erdos_ordman_split (1994):**

Every split graph on n vertices needs ≤ 3n²/16 + O(n) cliques.

**Note:** 3/16 = 0.1875, which is between 1/6 ≈ 0.167 (conjectured) and 1/4 ≈ 0.25 (general chordal).

Since the extremal construction is a split graph, this is already close to optimal for that case.

title: The Main Conjecture
content:
**erdos_81_conjecture:**

Every chordal graph on n vertices can have its edges partitioned into ≤ n²/6 + O(n) cliques.

**If true:** The extremal split graph construction is essentially tight.

**Status:** OPEN - neither proved nor disproved.

title: Simplicial Vertex
content:
**IsSimplicial G v:**

A vertex v is simplicial if its neighbors form a clique.

**Example:** In a complete graph, every vertex is simplicial.

Simplicial vertices are key to the perfect elimination ordering characterization of chordal graphs.

title: Chordal ↔ Perfect Elimination Ordering
content:
**chordal_iff_peo:**

A graph is chordal if and only if it has a perfect elimination ordering.

**PEO:** An ordering where each vertex is simplicial in the induced subgraph of remaining vertices.

This gives a polynomial-time recognition algorithm for chordal graphs.

title: Main Theorem: OPEN
content:
**erdos_81:**

**STATUS:** OPEN

**QUESTION:** Can every chordal graph on n vertices have edges partitioned into n²/6 + O(n) cliques?

**BOUNDS:**
- Lower: n²/6 (extremal split graph)
- Upper: (1/4 - ε)n² (Erdős-Ordman-Zalcstein)
- Split graphs: 3n²/16 (Chen-Erdős-Ordman)

**KEY INSIGHT:** The extremal example is a split graph, suggesting they may be the hardest case.
